questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

Drag and drop the characteristic from the left onto the cable type on the right.

//IMG//

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Each router must be configured with the last usable IP address in the subnet. Which configuration fulfills this requirement?

discussion.content:
You can do this fairly easily by process of elimination.

Starting with R7, a /26 is .192, so that leaves us with A or D.
The first difference between A and D is the last octet, 127 or 126 (respectively).

Do whatever process you prefer for subnetting and we figure that .126 is the last usable. .127 is the broadcast. 

Answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
Just by eliminating options.. the correct for R7 is option D

Selected Answer: D
As mentioned in the question we need the last usable IP address 
so remember the rule 

Network ID Even
First IP Odd
Last IP Even
Broadcast Address Odd

So starting with Router 7 we know that the subnet is 192 so now we have 2 options A and D and we know last IP should be even so answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer.
it's enough to look only R7 and answer is D

Selected Answer: D
Just look at the subnets mask.for r7 “/26” = .192 because 128 plus 64. Then for r8 “/28 “ = .240 because 128+64+32+16 that only leaves option d

comments.content: Regarding the last usable up address for r7 because it’s /26 the subnets are going to be every 64 numbers specifically r7 .128 is the network up for the next subnet .127 is the broadcast and .126 is the last useable ip

comments.content: I think its D. Check the answers again. The only difference between B and D is that in B, R9 subnet mask ends with .248, but it should be .224, because its a /27 network.
But why it has to be 224 and not 248 ?

Because a /27 is .224

A .248 would be /29. R9 is not /29.
because if 248 then i t will be /29.

choices.A: R7# interface FastEthernet1/0 ip address 10.88.31.127 255.255.255.192 R8# interface FastEthernet0/0 ip address 10.19.63.95 255.255.255.240 R9# interface FastEthernet1/1 ip address 10.23.98.159 255.255.255.224
choices.C: R7# interface FastEthernet1/0 ip address 10.88.31.127 255.255.255.240 R8# interface FastEthernet0/0 ip address 10.19.63.95 255.255.255.192 R9# interface FastEthernet1/1 ip address 10.23.98.159 255.255.255.248
choices.B: R7# interface FastEthernet1/0 ip address 10.88.31.126 255.255.255.240 R8# interface FastEthernet0/0 ip address 10.19.63.94 255.255.255.192 R9# interface FastEthernet1/1 ip address 10.23.98.158 255.255.255.248
choices.D: R7# interface FastEthernet1/0 ip address 10.88.31.126 255.255.255.192 R8# interface FastEthernet0/0 ip address 10.19.63.94 255.255.255.240 R9# interface FastEthernet1/1 ip address 10.23.98.158 255.255.255.224

this question appears 6 different times in this dump, so pretty safe to say you'll see this one on your exam.
given answers are correct
It should be good at the exam

Correct. single-mode fiber does have a core diameter of 9 microns. Single-mode fiber is designed to carry only one mode of light, which allows for a higher bandwidth and longer transmission distances compared to multimode fiber. The core diameter of single-mode fiber is significantly smaller than that of multimode fiber, which typically has a core diameter of 50 or 62.5 microns.
